repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Professor emeritus of English and Creative Writing at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs; novelist; son of Duke University faculty member William M. Blackburn. Writings and correspondence of Alexander Blackburn, including books, correspondence, drafts, and typescripts of unpublished works. Also includes Blackburn and Cheney family history materials, photographs, and a scrapbook.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access note. Collection contains fragile audiovisual/photographic formats that may need to be reformatted before use. Contact Research Services for access.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Alexander Blackburn Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Alexander Blackburn Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 1999, 2004, and 2020.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Accessioned by Meghan Lyon, January 2010 and Laurin Penland, January 2020.
Materials may not have been ordered and described beyond their original condition.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Alexander Blackburn (b. 1929) is the son of William Blackburn and Elizabeth Cheney Bayne Blackburn. He is a graduate of the University of North Carolina (M.A., 1956) and the University of Cambridge (Ph.D., 1963). He served in the U. S. Army during the Korean War before becoming a professor of English and literature at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs in 1973. His interests and writings center on the American West; he has also published a critical study on the writer-philosopher Frank Waters. Blackburn also founded and edited the Writers' Forum literary journal. He retired 1995 but continues to write and publish. His books and novels include the following:

item.title: Creative Spirit: Toward a Better World
A Sunrise Brighter Still: The Visionary Novels of Frank Waters
The Cold War of Kitty Pentecost
The Myth of the Picaro: Continuity and Transformation of the Picaresque Novel, 1554-1954

bioghist.p: More information on Alexander Blackburn can be found at his website, www.alexanderblackburn.com. His autobiography, Meeting the Professor (2008), details both his life and that of his father, William Blackburn.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection contains two accessions. Accession (1999-0184) (1102 items; 6.0 lin. ft.; dated 1953-1998), consists primarily of writings by Alexander Blackburn, including books, articles, clippings, and typescripts of unpublished works. Also included are correspondence with writer Frank Waters and some other letters; memorabilia; and editorial files and an almost complete run of the literary journal, Writer's Forum, which Blackburn edited.

Accession (2010-0012) (6750 items; 9 lin. ft.; dated 1880-1990s) and accession (2020-0099; 11.5 lin. ft) includes writings, drafts, books, and family history materials. Included are materials from Alexander Blackburn's mother, Elizabeth Cheney Blackburn, and the Cheney family.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Related collections include the William Blackburn Papers, 1859-1985 and undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accession (1999-0184) (dated 1953-1998) consists primarily of writings by Alexander Blackburn, including books, articles, clippings, and typescripts of unpublished works. Also included is correspondence with writer Frank Waters and some other letters; memorabilia; and editorial files and an almost complete run of the literary journal, Writer's Forum, which Blackburn edited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1 and 3 are missing. The bound copy of Vol. 5 is damaged, but an unbound complete text is attached. Vol. 11, the Frank Waters Issue, is an extremely rare book. Vol. 17, with Index to Vols. 1-16, has some cover damage. Vol. 22 was edited by A.B.'s successor, C. Kenneth Pellow

did.unittitle: Studies in Frank Waters. Edited by Charles Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Vol. 5 (1982) through Vol. 19 (1997), missing Vol. 17 (1995). A.B. frequently wrote essays for this periodical containing papers submitted for the annual conjoint meeting of The Frank Waters Society and the Rocky Mountain Modern Language Association.

Frank Waters.Dictionary of Literary Biography 1986, Includes manuscript and correspondence.

unittitle.title: Sight: The Magazine of Psychological Warfare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Only extant copy of this Army publication edited by A.B.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Editorial correspondence with writers and other material relevant (especially) to founding the magazine in 1974-75. There are some letters, too, from such well-known writers as Yusef Komunyakaa. See also Box 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accession (2010-0012) (6750 items; 9 lin. ft.; dated 1880-1990s) includes writings, drafts, books, and family history materials. Included are materials from Alexander Blackburn's mother, Elizabeth Cheney Blackburn, and the Cheney family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes writings, drafts, books, and family history materials. A more detailed inventory of the boxes is included in Acc 2020/99: Box 1.

did.unittitle: Writings by Blackburn, detailed inventory of Acc. 2020-0099

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The typed inventory was provided by Blackburn and may not match the current box numbers. Researchers will need to consult materials to confirm inventory. This box also includes books Blackburn wrote, edited, or to which Blackburn contributed. Titles are: "The Fire Within"; "The Myth of the Picaro"; "Meeting the Professor"; "Gifts from the Heart"; "The Cold War of Kitty Pentecost"; "Suddenly a Mortal Splendor"; "The Voice of the Children in the Apple Tree"; "The Door of the Sad People"; "Pure Waters: Frank Waters and the Quest for the Cosmic"; "Great Oaks: Memoirs of the Cheney Family"; "Old Manchester"; "Age of Atoms"; "The Emergence of Frank Waters".

Essays, letters, clippings, photographs, family history
Correspondence, clippings, awards, writings, and photographs relating to Blackburn's education and career

scopecontent.p: Correspondents include: Myrial A. Holbrook; Joanne Greenberg; Rudolfo A. Anaya; David Blackburn; Philip Blackburn; Rufus Phillips; Phaedra Greenwood; William deBuys; Angela Davis-Gardner; John Nichols; Leigh Cross; Jeffrey Putnam; Gladys Swan; Betsy Packard; George Blackburn, Jr.; Waring Blackburn; Lawrence Gustafson; Joan Mellon; and Emily Haskett (for Alan Polsky).

scopecontent.p: Includes materials relating to Alexander Blackburn and other family members including William Blackburn, Elizabeth Cheney Blackburn, and Roma Blackburn.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Yusef Komunyakaa and John Nizalowski; a notebook on Harvey Allen's poetry; and a typescript of Remembering Time.
